Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children - Fifth Edition(WISC-V)(This should follow styles: underline, strong and p tag)
The Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children– Fifth Edition (WISC-V) is an individually-administered, standardized measure of intellectual ability for children and adolescents ages 6 years to 16 years, 11 months. This instrument consists of 10 core subtests, which yield scaled scores with a mean of 10 and a standard deviation of 3. Subtest scores are combined to produce 4 composite standard scores as well as the full scale intelligence quotient, each with a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15. The mean is the average score based on the performance of the standardization sample and the standard deviation is the average variation of scores from the mean.

•	Below Average (SS: 71-84)

•	Above Average (SS: 116-129)
•	Significantly Above Average (SS: 130 and above)

Test of Auditory Processing Skills, 4th Edition(TAPS-4)(This should follow styles: underline, strong and p tag)
The Test of Auditory Processing Skills – Fourth Edition (TAPS-4) is an individually administered standardized measure of language processing and comprehension skills for individuals between 5 and 21 years of age. The TAPS-4 is designed to assess three intersecting areas: phonological processing, auditory memory, and listening comprehension. These areas are the foundation to the development of high order language skills, including reading skills. Phonological processing, auditory memory and listening comprehension are different than hearing. Hearing refers to the physical behaviors of the eardrum vibrating against the middle ear which stimulates the inner ear. Phonological processing refers to the process of the brain detecting and processing meaningful nonverbal information in sound. Auditory memory is the process in which the brain is able to encode, maintain, and manipulate information in one’s immediate consciousness. Listening comprehension is the ability to understand speech. All scores are reported in Standard Scores with the mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15.

AUTISM
C.C.R., § 3030(b) (1)

Autism means a developmental disability significantly affecting verbal and nonverbal communication and social interaction, generally evident before age three, and adversely affecting a child's educational performance. Other characteristics often associated with autism are engagement in repetitive activities and stereotyped movements, resistance to environmental change or change in daily routines, and unusual responses to sensory experiences.
(A) 	Autism does not apply if a child's educational performance is adversely affected primarily because the child has an emotional disturbance
(B) 	A child who manifests the characteristics of autism after age three could be identified as having autism if the criteria in this section are satisfied. Observations, interviews, records, and rating scales were utilized in order to gather data regarding symptoms of autism.

Academic Support Recommendations:
•	Extended Time on Assignments & Assessments: Due to Isabella’s challenges with processing speed and working memory, allow extra time to complete tasks, tests, and in-class assignments.
•	Chunking Assignments: Break assignments into smaller, manageable sections with clear, step-by-step instructions.
•	Alternative Assignment Formats: Allow Isabella to present information in various ways (e.g., oral presentations, videos, drawing) rather than requiring extensive written assignments.

Behavioral and Social-Emotional Support Recommendations:
•	Social Skills Training: Implement structured social skills groups to help (NAME) improve peer interactions, learn social norms, and manage interpersonal relationships effectively.
•	Behavior Intervention Plan (BIP): Develop a structured behavior plan with clear expectations, rewards, and consequences to address impulse control, hyperactivity, and compliance issues.
•	Self-Regulation Strategies: Teach and reinforce coping strategies such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness, and sensory breaks.

Executive Functioning and Organizational Skills Recommendations:
•	Daily Planner or Agenda: Encourage the use of an organizational tool to help Isabella keep track of assignments, deadlines, and upcoming tests.
•	Task Initiation Support: Provide prompts and cues to help her get started on tasks, as she may struggle with initiation.
•	Structured Transitions: Prepare Isabella for transitions between activities by using countdowns, timers, or verbal reminders.

Environmental Modifications:
•	Reduced Distractions in the Classroom: Limit excessive visual and auditory distractions in her learning environment.
•	Flexible Seating Options: Allow (NAME) to choose from various seating options (standing desk, wobble chair, etc.) to support focus and sensory needs.
•	Sensory Tools: Provide fidget tools, noise-canceling headphones, or other sensory supports as needed.
